1917 FUND WELL UNDER WAY
Class Votes for System of Direct Graded
Payments—Committee Sets About
Securing of Pledges to
Amount of $25,000.

At a class meeting held last
Wednesday in the Mechanical Enginering Building, the Class of
1917 gave its formal approval to
the plan submitted by its committee to raise an endowment fund
of at least $25,000 for the University within the next twenty years,
and instructed the committee to
begin the actual work of securing
the pledges immediately.
The plan adopted is that every
man in the class who wishes to
do so shall pledge himself to make
twenty annual payments to the•
fund—the first to consist of six
dollars, the second eight dollars
and so on each year bringing an
ailditionaf two-dollar increase, until the twentieth payment will
consist of forty-four dollars.
These payments are to be made
directly to an account created by
the class, which is not to be
touched until the period of twenty years stipulated shall have expired. The committee in charge
of the fund will be the same as
the one appointed to investigate
the possibility of its establishment
—Edward M. Stuart (chairman);
Paul W. Sutton and Reuben Oppenheimer.
Dr. Shenton, of the mathematics
department, has estimated for :the
class that the payments of each
man, while amounting to only
$500, at the end of the twentieth
year, by compound interest, will
have mounted up to $623.
The purpose of the graded payments is to make them as easy for
the men as possible. It was estimated that the hardest years of
each graduate would be the first
few to come, and that after this
preliminary period the tangible
results of a college education
would have begun to show themselves in the form of an increased
earning capacity. In this way, it
was figured, a man will probably
be in a much better position to
pay his last installment of fortyfour dollars at the end of the
twentieth year than he would be
to pay the twenty-five dollar installment next year, which would
be necessitated if the payments
were not graded.
Every effort is being made by
the committee to have the pledges
signed by the members of the
class as soon as possible, as many
of the seniors expect to leave for
the officers' training camp within
the next week.
The plan, in its final form, has
met with the hearty approval of
Professors Hollander a ml Barnett, of the political economy department, as the one which, all
things considered, has the best
chance of success. It is expected
that if the fund wanted is
pledged, the plan will be followed
by succeeding classes.

WASHINGTON.
April 14, 1917.
My dear Mr. President:
Your letter of April 11th
reached me promptly, but I have
been unhappily too much occupied
even to see my private correspondence until this late Saturday afternoon. I am sending your
letter at once to General Wood at
Governors Island, who will have
at least the primary and advisory
function of selecting camp sites
and will be interested in the great
facilities of Johns Hopkins, although he has before him already
a number of collegiate groups
which have been offered for the
same purpose. Our plan, as you
have perhaps learned from the
newspapers, is to organize a number of schools for rapid and intensive training of officers. Beyond that intention, we have not
been able to go because we have
not been able to learn just what
Congress will do with our legislation. I will ask General Wood to
communicate directly with you if
the site suggested and the facilities offered make him desire further details.
In the meantime, on behalf of
the Government and of this Department, I thank you most heartily for your generous suggestion.
Cordially yours,
NEWTON D. BAKER,
Secretary of War.

Attendance at Drills.

The criticism which Lieutenant
.Elliott directs against the spirit
of those men who have enlisted
in the corps and who have failed
to attend drills with regularity is
both severe and deserved. Whether
the particular individ ft al concerned finds that te is ineligible
for active service or not at the
present time, nevertheless the
preparation which the corps affords is bound to stand him in
good stead when his time arrives
—besides which there is involved
the very much more important
factor of fulfilling a tacit pledge.
THE NEWS - LETTER does not
agree with its vehement correspondent in this week's Mail Bag,
who claims that the activities of
the corps should almost entirely
supplant the regular University
curriculum. The drill provided is
neither onerous enough for such
action, nor would the University
be best serving its country by pursuing such a course. With only
three drills a week, however, no
man can take refuge for his nonattendance behind the claim that
his studies prevent hint from carrying on his military training.
This week, with three Hopkins
men sailing for France, Hopkins
again proves the depth of the patriotism of its students. What
'those who remain behind,and who,
at the present time, foresee no way

in which they may enter actual
service, must realize, is that they
can manifest their patriotism
very effectually by helping in the
development of the Hopkins Corps.
The Musical Clubs.

The Johns Hopkins Musical
Clubs never quite receive the apr
preciation from the University
which should be theirs by right.
In other institutions, where the
quality of the concerts given is
not a whit better than those which
the Hopkins musicians produce,
support of the 'varsity clubs is
looked upon by the students and
alumni from the same viewpoint
as is the support of the athletic
teams; but at Hopkins that support is very seldom forthcoming
in anything like the degree deserved.
Apart from the very definite
part in the creation of what small
"college life" there has existed at
Hopkins in the past, the clubs for
several years have consistently
brought the University before the
public eye throughout the city
and State. That the advertising
function which the organization
able to fulfill_should be as limited as it is, goes back to the obvious fact that Hopkins as yet is
not as fortunate in the number
of its alumni scattered about the
country as are other universities.
Nevertheless, even when this fact
has been taken into consideration,
neither alumni nor students at
Hopkins have accorded the clubs
the support which they deserve.
The season which the clubs have
just brought to a close repre-s
sents a protracted period of
steady, and often tiring, work performed by every member of the
organization —performed without
the official recognition which the
University accords to other student services. Not only have the
clubs of the past few years succeeded in producing concerts which
compare not unfavorably with the
concerts ,of any university of similar size in the country, and even
with the work of the musicians
of larger institutions; but, entirely under student direction, they
have succeeded in putting themselves upon a solid financial basis
which, in itself, when natural handicaps are considered, represents
quite an achievement.
Certainly the members of the
clubs during the past season are
as much to be congratulated upon
their work as are the members of
any other student activity.

MUSICAL CLUBS FINISH SEASON

HOPKINS NAVAL MEN ON LEAVE

Concert at Catonsville Marks End of Unusually Successful Year —Plan Under
Way for Award of Medals to
Faithful Members.

Five of the Hopkins Students With the
Naval Militia Visit the University
While on Furlough—Active
Service Anticipated.

With the final concert at the
Catonsville High School last Friday night, the Musical Clubs completed one of the most successful
seasons they have ever enjoyed.
The large number of concerts
throughout the city were unusually well attended; the trip to
Tome was a success in every way,
and the clubs only regret that they
were forced to call off the tour
through West Virginia on account
of insufficient guarantees from the
cities they had hoped to visit.
The season will also probably
turn out very well financially for
the musicians, for though there
may not be so much left over as
there was last year, on account
of the much - greater expense of
the McCoy Hall concert this year,
nevertheless the clubs will undoubtedly do better than split
even.
The clubs are considering the
advisability of awarding medals
to those members who have rendered faithful service for several
years. The plans for this have not
as yet been sufficiently matured
for publication, but it is probable
that something of this kind will
be announce:I in the near future.
The members of the clubs this
year were as follows:

Five Hopkins students were
among the members of the Maryland Naval Militia who returned
to the city last week during their
leave of forty-eight hours. The
men were Ferdinand Meyer, Ronald Cox, Warren Allen, Roger
Howell and Richard Woodward.
The Maryland Naval Militia, together with parts of the New Jersey, New York and Michigan
militia organizations, are in training on the "Indiana," where they
spend their time from five in the
morning until sundown or later
in learning the duties of a sailor.
As the various boats of the "mosquito fleet" and as the different
battleships, torpedo boats, etc.,
are put into commission, small
detachments of the militia Are
transferred from the "Indiana" to
the new ships.
All the Maryland men expect
to be put into active service at
any minute.
The Hopkins Members of the
Naval Militia are in excellent
health and are well pleased with
life in the Navy. They have the
distinction of being the first of
the University students to actively, take up arms for the defense of
the country during the present
'war.
The Hopkins men with the Naval Militia include many leaders
of student activities. Meyer, Hoffman and Wool ward were on the
lacrosse team, Woodward was
captain-elect and Hoffman and
Cox were members of the football
team, while Allen was president
of the Sophomore Class and Howell was a member of the baseball
team. Howell received his Ph. D.
degree this year.

1917 FUND WELL UNDER WAY
Class Votes for System of Direct Graded
Payments—Committee Sets About
Securing of Pledges to
Amount of $25,000.

At a class meeting held last
Wednesday in the Mechanical Enginering Building, the Class of
1917 gave its formal approval to
the plan submitted by its committee to raise an endowment fund
of at least $25,000 for the University within the next twenty years,
and instructed the committee to
begin the actual work of securing
the pledges immediately.
The plan adopted is that every
man in the class who wishes to
do so shall pledge himself to make
twenty annual payments to the•
fund—the first to consist of six
dollars, the second eight dollars
and so on each year bringing an
ailditionaf two-dollar increase, until the twentieth payment will
consist of forty-four dollars.
These payments are to be made
directly to an account created by
the class, which is not to be
touched until the period of twenty years stipulated shall have expired. The committee in charge
of the fund will be the same as
the one appointed to investigate
the possibility of its establishment
—Edward M. Stuart (chairman);
Paul W. Sutton and Reuben Oppenheimer.
Dr. Shenton, of the mathematics
department, has estimated for :the
class that the payments of each
man, while amounting to only
$500, at the end of the twentieth
year, by compound interest, will
have mounted up to $623.
The purpose of the graded payments is to make them as easy for
the men as possible. It was estimated that the hardest years of
each graduate would be the first
few to come, and that after this
preliminary period the tangible
results of a college education
would have begun to show themselves in the form of an increased
earning capacity. In this way, it
was figured, a man will probably
be in a much better position to
pay his last installment of fortyfour dollars at the end of the
twentieth year than he would be
to pay the twenty-five dollar installment next year, which would
be necessitated if the payments
were not graded.
Every effort is being made by
the committee to have the pledges
signed by the members of the
class as soon as possible, as many
of the seniors expect to leave for
the officers' training camp within
the next week.
The plan, in its final form, has
met with the hearty approval of
Professors Hollander a ml Barnett, of the political economy department, as the one which, all
things considered, has the best
chance of success. It is expected
that if the fund wanted is
pledged, the plan will be followed
by succeeding classes.

Attendance at Drills.

The criticism which Lieutenant
.Elliott directs against the spirit
of those men who have enlisted
in the corps and who have failed
to attend drills with regularity is
both severe and deserved. Whether
the particular individ ft al concerned finds that te is ineligible
for active service or not at the
present time, nevertheless the
preparation which the corps affords is bound to stand him in
good stead when his time arrives
—besides which there is involved
the very much more important
factor of fulfilling a tacit pledge.
THE NEWS - LETTER does not
agree with its vehement correspondent in this week's Mail Bag,
who claims that the activities of
the corps should almost entirely
supplant the regular University
curriculum. The drill provided is
neither onerous enough for such
action, nor would the University
be best serving its country by pursuing such a course. With only
three drills a week, however, no
man can take refuge for his nonattendance behind the claim that
his studies prevent hint from carrying on his military training.
This week, with three Hopkins
men sailing for France, Hopkins
again proves the depth of the patriotism of its students. What
'those who remain behind,and who,
at the present time, foresee no way

in which they may enter actual
service, must realize, is that they
can manifest their patriotism
very effectually by helping in the
development of the Hopkins Corps.
The Musical Clubs.

The Johns Hopkins Musical
Clubs never quite receive the apr
preciation from the University
which should be theirs by right.
In other institutions, where the
quality of the concerts given is
not a whit better than those which
the Hopkins musicians produce,
support of the 'varsity clubs is
looked upon by the students and
alumni from the same viewpoint
as is the support of the athletic
teams; but at Hopkins that support is very seldom forthcoming
in anything like the degree deserved.
Apart from the very definite
part in the creation of what small
"college life" there has existed at
Hopkins in the past, the clubs for
several years have consistently
brought the University before the
public eye throughout the city
and State. That the advertising
function which the organization
able to fulfill_should be as limited as it is, goes back to the obvious fact that Hopkins as yet is
not as fortunate in the number
of its alumni scattered about the
country as are other universities.
Nevertheless, even when this fact
has been taken into consideration,
neither alumni nor students at
Hopkins have accorded the clubs
the support which they deserve.
The season which the clubs have
just brought to a close repre-s
sents a protracted period of
steady, and often tiring, work performed by every member of the
organization —performed without
the official recognition which the
University accords to other student services. Not only have the
clubs of the past few years succeeded in producing concerts which
compare not unfavorably with the
concerts ,of any university of similar size in the country, and even
with the work of the musicians
of larger institutions; but, entirely under student direction, they
have succeeded in putting themselves upon a solid financial basis
which, in itself, when natural handicaps are considered, represents
quite an achievement.
Certainly the members of the
clubs during the past season are
as much to be congratulated upon
their work as are the members of
any other student activity.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 30, 1917.

MUSICAL CLUBS FINISH SEASON

HOPKINS NAVAL MEN ON LEAVE

Concert at Catonsville Marks End of Unusually Successful Year —Plan Under
Way for Award of Medals to
Faithful Members.

Five of the Hopkins Students With the
Naval Militia Visit the University
While on Furlough—Active
Service Anticipated.

With the final concert at the
Catonsville High School last Friday night, the Musical Clubs completed one of the most successful
seasons they have ever enjoyed.
The large number of concerts
throughout the city were unusually well attended; the trip to
Tome was a success in every way,
and the clubs only regret that they
were forced to call off the tour
through West Virginia on account
of insufficient guarantees from the
cities they had hoped to visit.
The season will also probably
turn out very well financially for
the musicians, for though there
may not be so much left over as
there was last year, on account
of the much - greater expense of
the McCoy Hall concert this year,
nevertheless the clubs will undoubtedly do better than split
even.
The clubs are considering the
advisability of awarding medals
to those members who have rendered faithful service for several
years. The plans for this have not
as yet been sufficiently matured
for publication, but it is probable
that something of this kind will
be announce:I in the near future.
The members of the clubs this
year were as follows:

Shaw, '17; AiTiaS, '17; Gorman,
'17; Smith, '17; Hurwitz, '17;

Kahn, '18; • Wells, '18; Duncan,
'18; Hardman, '18; Prince, '19;
Melamet, '19; Leber, '20, and
Coulter, '20.

'19; Coonin, '19; Mercerau, '20;.
H. C. Davis, '20, and Speirs, '20.

Five Hopkins students were
among the members of the Maryland Naval Militia who returned
to the city last week during their
leave of forty-eight hours. The
men were Ferdinand Meyer, Ronald Cox, Warren Allen, Roger
Howell and Richard Woodward.
The Maryland Naval Militia, together with parts of the New Jersey, New York and Michigan
militia organizations, are in training on the "Indiana," where they
spend their time from five in the
morning until sundown or later
in learning the duties of a sailor.
As the various boats of the "mosquito fleet" and as the different
battleships, torpedo boats, etc.,
are put into commission, small
detachments of the militia Are
transferred from the "Indiana" to
the new ships.
All the Maryland men expect
to be put into active service at
any minute.
The Hopkins Members of the
Naval Militia are in excellent
health and are well pleased with
life in the Navy. They have the
distinction of being the first of
the University students to actively, take up arms for the defense of
the country during the present
'war.
The Hopkins men with the Naval Militia include many leaders
of student activities. Meyer, Hoffman and Wool ward were on the
lacrosse team, Woodward was
captain-elect and Hoffman and
Cox were members of the football
team, while Allen was president
of the Sophomore Class and Howell was a member of the baseball
team. Howell received his Ph. D.
degree this year.
